name: Cosmological Redshift
explanation: Redshift (z) measures how much light wavelengths stretch due to universe expansion. z = Δλ/λ_emit. For nearby objects: z ≈ v/c. For distant objects, cosmological redshift reveals expansion history. Used to measure distances, velocities, and study early universe. High redshift objects are very distant and old.

examples.problem: Hydrogen line (656 nm) observed at 1312 nm. What is redshift?

examples.solution: Wavelength doubled, universe was half current size when light was emitted
steps: Light emitted when universe was half current size
